conclusion: Determine if the pedestrian can catch up with the bus by analyzing distances as functions of time.
Pedestrian runs at a constant speed of 8 m/s.
Distance covered by the pedestrian as a function of time is x_p(t) = 8t.
Bus starts from rest and accelerates uniformly, reaching 8 m/s in 8 s.
Acceleration of the bus is 1 m/s^2.
Distance covered by the bus as a function of time is x_b(t) = 0.5t^2.
Pedestrian starts 36 meters behind the bus.
Relative distance between pedestrian and bus is Δx(t) = 0.5t^2 + 36 - 8t.
Solve for t when Δx(t) = 0 to find if pedestrian can catch up.
Use quadratic formula to solve: t = (16 ± √(-32))/2.
Discriminant is negative, no real solutions, Δx(t) never zero.
Pedestrian cannot catch up with the bus.
